title: Quiz 7: Environmental Microbiology
description: Evaluate your understanding of microbes in the environment, including soil ecology, aquatic systems, and air quality.

questions.question: The soil region in direct contact with plant roots, which is enriched in nutrients, is called the ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The rhizosphere is the zone surrounding plant roots where biology and chemistry are influenced by the root.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a symbiotic nitrogen-fixing relationship?
questions.explanation: Rhizobia bacteria live in legume root nodules and fix nitrogen for the plant.
questions.hint: It helps grow beans and peas.

questions.question: Which factors affect microbial abundance in soils? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Moisture, oxygen, pH, temperature, and nutrients are key factors.
questions.hint: Think of what plants also need.

questions.question: Match the water quality standard with the acceptable fecal coliform limit:

richContent.content:
Water TypeLimit (/100ml)
Drinking0
Recreational200

questions.explanation: Drinking water must be sterile of coliforms; recreational water allows some.
questions.hint: You drink it, it must be zero.

questions.question: Air is a nutrient-rich medium that supports active microbial growth.
questions.explanation: Air is a poor medium for growth (too dry, low nutrients); it mainly serves to transport microbes.

questions.question: What is the study of life present in the air called?
questions.explanation: Aerobiology is the study of airborne organic particles, including microbes.

questions.question: In aquatic microbiology, which zone constitutes about 70% of the total Earth area?
questions.explanation: Oceans (marine systems) cover ~70% of the planet.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an efficient method of transferring microbes through air?
questions.explanation: Sneezing, coughing, and talking create droplets. Osmosis is water movement across a membrane.
questions.hint: One is a biological process in water.

questions.question: Symbiotic nitrogen fixation yields significantly more nitrogen per hectare than free-living fixation.
questions.explanation: Symbiotic fixation yields ~100kg/hectare vs 25kg/hectare for free-living.

questions.question: Which organisms are used as 'indicator organisms' for water contamination?
questions.explanation: Coliforms (like E. coli) indicate fecal contamination.
